Headers.summary: The Headers interface of the Fetch API allows you to perform various actions on HTTP request and response headers. These actions include retrieving, setting, adding to, and removing headers from the list of the request's headers.

remarks.para: A Headers object has an associated header list, which is initially empty and consists of zero or more name and value pairs. You can add to this using methods like (see Examples.) In all methods of this interface, header names are matched by case-insensitive byte sequence.
For security reasons, some headers can only be controlled by the user agent. These headers include the Forbidden_header_name and Forbidden_response_header_name.

A Headers object also has an associated guard, which takes a value of immutable, request, request-no-cors, response, or none. This affects whether the , , and methods will mutate the header. For more information see {{Glossary("Guard")}}.
You can retrieve a Headers object via the and properties, and create a new Headers object using the constructor.

An object implementing Headers can directly be used in a {{jsxref("Statements/for...of", "for...of")}} structure, instead of : for (const p of myHeaders) is equivalent to for (const p of myHeaders.entries()).

blockquote.para: Note: you can find out more about the available headers by reading our HTTP headers reference.
